greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Table T(n,k) counts the involutions of n with longest increasing contiguous subsequence of length k.
example: T(4,2) = 6 because the 6 involutions with longest increasing contiguous subsequence lengths equal to 2 are: 1324, 1432, 2143, 3214, 3412, 4231.
mathematica: maxISS[perm_List] := Max[0, (Max @@ (Length[#1]*Sign[First[#1]] & ) /@ Split[Sign[Rest[#1] - Drop[#1, -1]]] & )[perm]];classMaxISS[par_?PartitionQ]:=Count[ maxISS/@( TableauxToPermutation[FirstLexicographicTableau[par], #]&/@Tableaux[par]  ) ,#]&/@(-1+Range[ Tr[par] ]);
xref: Cf. A008304; row sums are A000085; A047884 removes the contiguity requirement.
results.author: _Wouter Meeussen_, Dec 20 2010
